article_title: Why has the rate of abortions shifted downward? Experts are divided
article_text:
Times have changed since Phyllis Wetherby manned a phone line for the National Organization for Women, taking calls from women looking for financial assistance to get an abortion.

That was back in the ’70s and ’80s.

Now Ms. Wetherby, president of the First Pittsburgh chapter of NOW, no longer receives such calls, and abortion rates across the state have decreased from a peak number of abortions in 2008.

After the rate of abortions in Pennsylvania steadily rose between 2005 to 2008, by 2013 the rate dropped by 17.3 percent from a 2008 high of 38,807 abortions, according to state health department figures recently released. With 32,108 abortions, 2013 had the lowest annual number of abortions ever recorded in Pennsylvania. Figures for 2014 and 2015 are not yet available.

Here in Pittsburgh there are mixed views about what is causing the decline.

A national compilation of state health department data collected by the Associated Press earlier this month found that there has been an overall 12 percent drop in the number of abortions performed nationwide between 2010 and 2013. Pennsylvania’s drop during that same period was just a smidgen above the national rate, at 12.7 percent. Compared with other states, Pennsylvania had the fifth highest annual number of abortions, preceded by New York, Florida, Texas and Illinois, respectively.

The age group most likely to have an abortion was 20-24, and almost all abortions occurred during the first 14 weeks of pregnancy.

For Marlene Wohleber, former president and current website administrator of the anti-abortion group People Concerned for the Unborn Child, this trend is strongly indicative of a growing awareness of the humanity of the unborn child.

Ms. Wohleber said that the activities of the anti-abortion community, including protesting outside abortion clinics and putting up billboards that tell women they have options besides abortion have contributed largely to the decline.

Mary Lou Gartner, the political director of PCUC, said the introduction of ultrasounds now allow women to see the fetus at a very early stage.

“The claim that it is just a blob of tissue no longer holds any weight,” she said.

Susan Frietsche, senior staff attorney at the Women’s Law Project and abortion rights activist, said that there is no evidence for a shift in public opinion against abortion.

She cited the findings of a 2014 Gallup study, which showed that Americans have been split roughly evenly between support and opposition to abortion since 2010.

Ms. Frietsche added that restrictions against abortion, ranging from legal restrictions to campaigns led by anti-abortion groups, do not affect abortion rates.

“I think that women will do anything to get an abortion when they need it, and that they will do anything to maintain a pregnancy if that’s what they want,” she said.

Aleigha Cavalier, public affairs director at Planned Parenthood of Western Pennsylvania, said that the drop in abortion rates is due to greater access to contraception and better sexual education.

She said that Planned Parenthood has seen a 91 percent increase in the use of IUDs and implants since 2010. Both are considered the most effective forms of reversible birth control available, according to the American College of Gynecology and Obstetricians. Ms. Cavalier added that the Affordable Care Act has also contributed to the decline in abortions, with its mandate of improved contraceptive coverage.

Unplanned pregnancies still happen, Ms. Gartner said, and women can make a choice between ending or continuing their pregnancy. There has been a shift in public opinion, she said, and fewer women choose abortions.

“It’s a decision that women have to make at that stage in their lives, and we think that more women are choosing life,” she said.

Micaiah Bilger, education director at the Pennsylvania Pro-Life Federation, agreed. She added that women have more support to manage unplanned pregnancies, such as free counseling, diapers, help with rent and scholarships to get them through college.

More research is needed to discern which factors are affecting the rate of abortions, said Ms. Frietsche.

“This needs more study, women don't decide to have an abortion lightly.”

Amaka Uchegbu: auchegbu@post-gazette.com, 412-263-3571, Twitter: @AmakaYDN.
